section.name: CONCEPTS IN NURSING: HEALTHY LIFE STYLES II

comments:
This course focuses on health promotion and disease prevention across the health-illness continuum for healthy and at risk individuals in the community. Students build on their previously mastered communication techniques and clinical skills to develop comprehensive assessment skills and to define needs among specific at risk groups in a family and community context. In weekly seminars, students integrate theories of behavior and health, epidemiologic principles, clinical decision making, and critical thinking skills. Theories are applied utilizing case studies and data sources to develop health promotion and disease prevention strategies. A key component of the course is the development of communication and physical assessment skills and specified clinical techniques. The influence of gender, life span, culture, race, and ethnicity on health promotion and disease prevention is specifically addressed throughout the course.

Most students commented on the value of this course for nursing students. They described lectures as mostly “informative”, interactive, yet, generally disorganized and inconsistent. While some students appreciated the small recitations and case studies that made them “think like a nurse”, others found the sessions “useless.”

The majority of classes were taught by different guest lecturers which confused many students who felt the class lacked consistency. Many students were expecting Professors George and Quigley to lecture more often. In addition, students complained that instruction quality was hit or miss depending on the individual guest lecturer. Some instructors were unwilling to answer questions prior to exams or discuss test answers after the fact. Many students described the instructors as “rigid” as they held to a “no re-grade” policy.

The course consisted of two tests, a final exam, a clinical grade, and a clinical issues paper. Almost all students complained that exams were unfair as the questions were worded poorly and multiple-choice options seemed interchangeable. Others described exam material as “arbitrary,” saying that it “did not reflect the content of the lectures.” Some students thought the final exam covered too much cumulative material to study thoroughly. Exams placed emphasis on the NCLEX style of thinking which students wished they had known while studying. NURS 54, 104, and 131 are prerequisites for this course and NURS 132 is a co-requisite.

This course focuses on health promotion and disease prevention across the health-illness continuum for healthy and at risk individuals in the community. Students build on their previously mastered communication techniques and clinical skills to develop comprehensive assessment skills and to define needs among specific at risk groups in a family and community context. In weekly seminars, students integrate theories of behavior and health, epidemiologic principles, clinical decision making, and critical thinking skills. Theories are applied utilizing case studies and data sources to develop health promotion and disease prevention strategies. A key component of the course is the development of communication and physical assessment skills and specified clinical techniques. The influence of gender, life span, culture, race, and ethnicity on health promotion and disease prevention is specifically addressed throughout the course.

Overall, students found the recitation helpful in learning nursing diagnoses and critical thinking skills. Some felt the case studies were too easy, straightforward, and “repetitive.” One student reported that the course could use more consistency among the professors but enjoyed the recitation as a learning opportunity.

This course was co-taught by Professors Quigley, Maldonado and George. Students praised Professor Quigley as “outstanding.” Students appreciated how the professors balanced memorization and critical thinking skills when discussing case studies. No other specific comments were made regarding Professors George and Maldonado.

Most students in this class were Nursing sophomores. The class is necessary to fulfill a major requirement and serves as a pre-requisite for many future nursing courses. Students recommend this course for majors but do not feel that non-Nursing majors should enroll in it. Pre-requisites for the class include NURS 54, 104, 131 with the co-requisite of NURS 132.
